description: Borrowed from Sanskrit मण्डप (maṇḍapa), मण्टप (maṇṭapa, “pavilion, mandapa”), a non-native word likely from the same source as मठ (maṭha, “hut, hermit's cottage”). Probably derived via Hindi मंडप (maṇḍap) or another New Indo-Aryan language.

entries.meaning: (in south India, architecture) A pillared hall or porch fronting a Hindu temple. It may be attached or detached from the building.
(South Asia) A temporary platform or sacred tent used for a wedding or other religious ceremony.
examples: She led the way inside the house to the mandap.
